| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    | [SLASH'EM\_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1026](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1026 "SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c") |

A **kobold warrior**, k, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). It is the strongest non-unique [kobold](/wiki/Kobold_\(monster_class\) "Kobold (monster class)") of those introduced in SLASH'EM, and has a weapon attack with a hit die twice as strong as a [kobold lord](/wiki/Kobold_lord "Kobold lord").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [5 References](#References)

## Generation

A kobold warrior [generates with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") either an [orcish spear](/wiki/Orcish_spear "Orcish spear") (1⁄4 chance) or a stack of darts (3⁄4 chance), and either an [orcish short sword](/wiki/Orcish_short_sword "Orcish short sword") (1⁄4 chance) or an [orcish dagger](/wiki/Orcish_dagger "Orcish dagger") (3⁄4 chance).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

As with [rock kobolds](/wiki/Rock_kobold "Rock kobold"), kobold warriors are distinctly more dangerous than kobolds in vanilla *NetHack*. Their [HD](/wiki/HD "HD") of 7 lets them take a few hits, and their weapon attack is twice as damaging as that of a [kobold lord](/wiki/Kobold_lord "Kobold lord"). Low-level or fragile characters will want to be cautious when they first appear, and all characters should be mindful of them when they appear in large groups with their brethren, such as on the [kobold level](/wiki/Kobold_level "Kobold level").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobold_\(Dungeons_%26_Dragons\) "wikipedia:Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)")***

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

*[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* in particular - and by extension, *NetHack* and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise *Record of Lodoss War*. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

## Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation  
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with  
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the  
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble  
for Elves at any time.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [makemon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 851](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c#line851 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c")

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Kobold warrior

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
k kobold warrior
Difficulty 8
Attacks Weapon 2d8
k kobold warrior
Difficulty 8
Attacks

Weapon 2d8

Base level 7
Base experience 97
Speed 9
Base AC 10
Base MR 0
Alignment -3 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 450
Nutritional value 150
Size Small
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed None

A kobold warrior:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
  • does not appear in Gehennom.
  • may turn against you when tame.
Reference SLASH'EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1026

A kobold warrior, k, is a type of monster that appears in SLASH'EM, SlashTHEM and Hack'EM. It is the strongest non-unique kobold of those introduced in SLASH'EM, and has a weapon attack with a hit die twice as strong as a kobold lord.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry
  • 5 References

Generation

A kobold warrior generates with either an orcish spear (1⁄4 chance) or a stack of darts (3⁄4 chance), and either an orcish short sword (1⁄4 chance) or an orcish dagger (3⁄4 chance).[1]

Strategy

As with rock kobolds, kobold warriors are distinctly more dangerous than kobolds in vanilla NetHack. Their HD of 7 lets them take a few hits, and their weapon attack is twice as damaging as that of a kobold lord. Low-level or fragile characters will want to be cautious when they first appear, and all characters should be mindful of them when they appear in large groups with their brethren, such as on the kobold level.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

Dungeons & Dragons in particular - and by extension, NetHack and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise Record of Lodoss War. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.


References

  1. ↑ makemon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 851

A '''kobold warrior''', {{monsym|kobold warrior}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]], [[SlashTHEM]] and [[Hack'EM]]. It is the strongest non-unique [[Kobold (monster class)|kobold]] of those introduced in SLASH'EM, and has a weapon attack with a hit die twice as strong as a [[kobold lord]].

==Generation==
A kobold warrior [[Monster starting inventory|generates with]] either an [[orcish spear]] ({{frac|4}} chance) or a stack of darts ({{frac|3|4}} chance), and either an [[orcish short sword]] ({{frac|4}} chance) or an [[orcish dagger]] ({{frac|3|4}} chance).{{refsrc|makemon.c|851|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

==Strategy==
As with [[rock kobold]]s, kobold warriors are distinctly more dangerous than kobolds in vanilla ''NetHack''.  Their [[HD]] of 7 lets them take a few hits, and their weapon attack is twice as damaging as that of a [[kobold lord]].  Low-level or fragile characters will want to be cautious when they first appear, and all characters should be mindful of them when they appear in large groups with their brethren, such as on the [[kobold level]].

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)}}
Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' in particular - and by extension, ''NetHack'' and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise ''Record of Lodoss War''. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|<poem>
The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?).  They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face.  They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.
</poem>}}
